facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 583 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 583 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal is by special leave from the Judgment and decree dated August 12, 1959, of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil Misc. First Appeal No. 50 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and decree dated August 12, 1959, of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil Misc. First Appeal No. 50 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 22, 1964 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: April 22, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.--The facts giving rise to this appeal, by special leave, are briefly as folows

facts.text: Respondent Bhooralal brought Civil Suit No. 20 of 1954 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Kekri against the appellant claiming possession of certain property and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent- Bhooralal-brought a suit-Civil Suit 20 1954-in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Kekri against the appellant claiming possession of certain property which was described in the plaint and for mesne profits.

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged absolute ownership of the property and wrongful possession by defendant despite demands.

anchor.surface_text: The allegation in the plaint was that the plaintiff was the absolute owner of the said property of which the defendant was in wrongful possession and that in spite of demands he had failed to vacate the same

facts.text: Reference in plaint to previous suit C.S. 28 of 1950 by plaintiff and his mother against defendant for mesne profits up to February 10, 1950, which was decreed.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint he made reference to a previous suit that had been filed by him and his mother  C.S. 28 of 1950  wherein a claim had been made against the defendant for the recovery of the mesne profits in regard to the same property for the period ending with February 10, 1950.

facts.text: In Written Statement, appellant disputed claims on merits and raised plea that O. 2. r. 2 CPC bars the suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the Written Statement that was filed by the present appellant, besides disputing the claim of the plaintiff to the reliefs prayed for on the merits, a technical plea to the maintainability of the suit was also raised in these terms

facts.text: Appellant pleaded that plaintiff omitted to sue for possession in previous suit CS 28/1950, hence barred from possession and further mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: That 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code is a bar to the suit. When the suit referred to in paragraph 2 of the plaint was filed the plaintiff had a cause of action for the reliefs also. He having omitted to sue for possession in that suit, is number barred from claiming relief of possession.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge framed 5 issues, including issue 4: Whether O. 2. r. 2 CPC is a bar.

anchor.surface_text: On these pleadings the learned Subordinate Judge framed 5 issues and of these the 4th issue ran Whether 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code is a bar?.

facts.text: Issue 4 argued as preliminary issue before trial judge, who found suit barred and dismissed it.

anchor.surface_text: Before evidence was led by the parties issue number 4 was argued before the learned trial Judge as a preliminary issue and the Court recorded a finding that the suit was barred by the provision named and directed the dismissal of the suit.

facts.text: Plaintiff appealed to Additional District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff preferred an appeal from this decree to the additional District Judge

facts.text: Additional District Judge held pleadings of earlier suit CS 28/1950 not on record, so O2 r2 plea not entertainable; alternatively causes of action different; set aside dismissal and remanded for merits.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellate Court companysidered this plea as regards the bar under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code on two alternative bases. In the first place, the learned District Judge pointed out that the pleadings in the earlier suit-C.S. 28 of 1950-had number been field in the case and made part of the record,

facts.text: Defendant appealed to Rajasthan High Court in second appeal, which was dismissed by Single Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant-the appellant before us-preferred a second appeal to the High Court of Rajasthan and the learned Single Judge dismissed this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave for this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It is from this judgment that the appellants have preferred this appeal after obtaining special leave.

facts.text: Pleadings of previous suit CS 28/1950 were not filed by appellant as evidence in support of O2 r2 plea.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the pleadings in C.S. 28 of 1950 were number filed by the appellant in the present suit as evidence in support of his plea under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code.

facts.text: Trial Judge inferred cause of action without previous pleadings on record.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge, however, without these pleadings being on the record inferred what the cause of action should have been from the reference to the previous suit companytained in the plaint as a matter of deduction.

facts.text: District Judge noticed lack of previous pleadings and rejected O2 r2 plea on that ground.

anchor.surface_text: At the stage of the appeal the learned District Judge numbericed this lacuna in the appelllants case and pointed out, in our opinion rightly, that without the plaint in the previous suit being on the record, a plea of a bar under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code was number main- tainable.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that O2 r2 plea requires previous plaint to be filed to prove identity of cause of action.

anchor.surface_text: It is for this reason that we companysider that a plea of a bar under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code can be established only if the defendant files in evidence the pleadings in the previous suit and thereby proves to the Court the identity of the cause of action in the two suits.

facts.text: High Court judgment noted that plaint of earlier suit not filed, but courts cited from it; however SC finds no such consent or admission.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant, however, drew our attention to a passage in the judgment of the learned Judge in the High Court which read LP D ISCl-27 a  The plaint, written statement or the judgment of the earlier companyrt has number been filed by any of the parties to the suit.

facts.text: Plaint in present suit in Hindi, 'mesne profits' is translation, original not before SC.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, it is admitted that the plaint in the present suit was in Hindi and that the word mesne profits is an English translation of some expression used in the original. The original of the plaint is number before us

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeal and affirms remand order.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore companysider that the order of remand passed by the learned Additional District Judge which was companyfirmed by the learned Judge in the High Court was right. The merits of the suit have yet to be tried and this has been directed by the order of remand which we are affirming. The appeal fails and is dismissed.

concepts.interpretation: Clause (3): A person entitled to more than one relief in respect of the same cause of action may sue for all or any of such reliefs, but if he omits, except with the leave of the Court, to sue for all such reliefs, he shall not afterwards sue for any reliefs so omitted.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the High Courts, notably Madras, have in this connection, referred to the terms of 0. 2. r. 4 which runs R. 4. No cause of action shall, unless with the leave of the Court, be joined with a suit for the recovery of immoveable property, except-  a  claims for mesne profits or arrears of rent in respect of the property claimed or any part thereof  b  claims for damages for breach of any contract under which the property or any part thereof is held and  c  claims in which the relief sought is based on the same cause of action Provided that nothing in this rule shall be deemed to prevent any party in a suit for foreclosure or redemption from asking to be put into possession of the mortgaged property.

concepts.interpretation: Used by some courts as aid to construe 'cause of action' in O2R2(3); indicates mesne profits claim can be separate from possession.

issues.text: Whether a suit for possession of immovable property and a suit for the recovery of mesne profits from the same property are both based on the same cause of action

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated, there is a conflict of judicial opinion on the question whether a suit for possession of immoveable property and a suit for the recovery of mesne profits from the same property are both based on the same cause of action, for it is only if these two reliefs are based on the same cause of action that the plea of 0. 2. r. 2., Civil Procedure Code

holdings.text: a plea of a bar under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code can be established only if the defendant files in evidence the pleadings in the previous suit and thereby proves to the Court the identity of the cause of action in the two suits

anchor.surface_text: a plea of a bar under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code can be established only if the defendant files in evidence the pleadings in the previous suit and thereby proves to the Court the identity of the cause of action in the two suits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Technical plea requires proof of precise cause of action in previous suit via its pleadings; cannot presume or infer from current plaint references or deductions

holdings.text: Just as in the case of a plea of res judicata which cannot be established in the absence on the record of the judgment and decree which is pleaded as estoppel, we consider that a plea under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code cannot be made out except on proof of the plaint in the previous suit the filing of which is said to create the bar

anchor.surface_text: Just as in the case of a plea of res judicata which cannot be established in the absence on the record of the judgment and decree which is pleaded as estoppel, we consider that a plea under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code cannot be made out except on proof

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.2 r.2 plea analogous to res judicata/estoppel, mandating production of previous plaint to establish cause of action identity

holdings.text: Nor can we find any basis for the suggestion that the learned Judge had admitted these documents at the second appeal stage under 0. 41. r. 27, Civil Procedure Code by consent of parties

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we find any basis for the suggestion that the learned Judge had admitted these documents at the second appeal stage under 0. 41. r. 27, Civil Procedure Code by consent of parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No record of agreement, consent, or order admitting previous suit documents as additional evidence in second appeal

holdings.text: the learned District Judge was right in holding that the appellant had not placed before the Court material for the purpose of founding a plea of 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the pleadings in C.S. 28 of 1950 were not filed by the appellant in the present suit as evidence in support of his plea under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code. The learned trial Judge, however, without these pleadings being on the record inferred what the cause of action should have been from the reference to the previous suit contained in the plaint as a matter of deduction. At the stage of the appeal the learned District Judge noticed this lacuna in the appellants case and pointed out, in our opinion rightly, that without the plaint in the previous suit being on the record, a plea of a bar under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code was not main- tainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court erred by inferring cause of action without previous pleadings; District Judge correctly rejected plea for lack of evidence

holdings.text: We therefore consider that the order of remand passed by the learned Additional District Judge which was confirmed by the learned Judge in the High Court was right

anchor.surface_text: We therefore consider that the order of remand passed by the learned Additional District Judge which was confirmed by the learned Judge in the High Court was right. The merits of the suit have yet to be tried and this has been directed by the order of remand which we are affirming. The appeal fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea of bar unsustainable without proof, affirming lower courts' remand for trial on merits

anchor.surface_text: a plea of a bar under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code can be established only if the defendant files in evidence the pleadings in the previous suit and thereby proves to the Court the identity of the cause of action in the two suits.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we find any basis for the suggestion that the learned Judge had admitted these documents at the second appeal stage under 0. 41. r. 27, Civil Procedure Code by consent of parties.

edges.explanation: Holding DJ right on no material supports holding remand order right

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the pleadings in C.S. 28 of 1950 were not filed by the appellant in the present suit as evidence in support of his plea under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code. The learned trial Judge, however, without these pleadings being on the record inferred what the cause of action should have been from the reference to the previous suit contained in the plaint as a matter of deduction. At the stage of the appeal the learned District Judge noticed this lacuna in the appellants case and pointed out, in our opinion rightly, that without the plaint in the previous suit being on the record, a plea of a bar under 0. 2. r. 2, Civil Procedure Code was not main- tainable.
The appeal fails and is dismissed.

We therefore consider that the order of remand passed by the learned Additional District Judge which was confirmed by the learned Judge in the High Court was right. The merits of the suit have yet to be tried and this has been directed by the order of remand which we are affirming. The appeal fails and is dismissed.
The appeal fails and is dismissed.
